text: well this may look like a Christmas tree
but in Russia they call it a new year
tree nava God new yorker because it's
new year which is the main holiday here
and how the Russians celebrated
traditionally with a big family feast
follow me let me introduce you this is
Daria who's very kindly let us into her
kitchen to show us how she makes one of
the most famous festive Russian dishes
something that you'll find at New Year's
part is the length and breadth of Russia
and that is the Olivier salad Daria what
do you put into this masterpiece well
the traditional ingredients for
traditional Russian you years salad
without reach the new year I think we'll
just not come in Russia our onion eggs
peas carrots salted cucumbers potatoes
boiled chicken breasts some parsley and
we will cover it all with mayonnaise
sounds absolutely delicious so Daria off
we go
and there we go the finished Olivier
salad very heavy and it smells
absolutely delicious but there's one
thing that leaves a bit of a sour taste
I have to say and that's the price
because Russian media have been
reporting that it now costs thirty
percent more to make this salad that it
did last year because prices are rising
on everything in Russia right now Daria
do you notice that you notice inflation
when you go to the shops of course I did
because I go for shopping and I buy
products and the average bill has grown
up to 30 and sometimes fifty percent
next year is expected to be a difficult
year in Russia with Russia moving into a
recession does that dampen your festive
spirit definitely not but i must say
that people are celebrating this new
year eve with a thought that let's have
a party for the last time without
thinking about money and it's quite
russian thank you very much Daria so as
you can see tough times ahead but
Russians still have a very big appetite
for a party oh I'm so sorry I broke your
